The certificate was developed using a comprehensive design process that began with empathizing with users and identifying pain points. Solutions were then generated through ideation, followed by the creation of wireframes and prototypes. Designs were rigorously tested and iterated upon. The process included conducting UX research studies, interviews, and usability studies, as well as synthesizing research results. Foundational UX concepts, such as user-centered design, accessibility, and equity-focused design, were applied throughout.

The master's thesis focused on optimizing the cabin design of delivery vehicles in China by applying a user experience (UX) analysis model and scientific methods. The goal was to enhance ergonomics and design a new vehicle cabin that addresses all user pain points. The thesis was titled 'Delivery Vehicle Optimization Using Jack Software.' Ultimately, the methodology proved successful in resolving posture issues.

The thesis focused on the development of a tourist application leveraging emerging technologies like augmented reality. The research employed a methodology grounded in design thinking to uncover insights into the Chilean tourist area of Cahuil. This area is renowned for its extraction of natural sea salt and holds the distinction of being a World Heritage Site. Despite its significance, Cahuil had low tourist visibility. Thus, the thesis aimed to create a technological solution to attract new tourists, offering them an enhanced and educational experience through technology.
